title: Lee Qi
text: Technically my first name is Qi, and my family name is Lee. I grew up as a Chinese Singaporean. In Chinese culture, family names typically come before your own name. Whereas in Singaporean culture, Chinese names are often two syllable names, rather than just one. As such I grew up being referred to as Lee Qi, instead of just Qi. Using Qi alone is more like a dimunitive nickname that my family and some childhood friends use.

title: Lee Qi
text:
My Education
I graduated with an International Baccalaureate diploma from the Lester B. Pearson United World College of the Pacific. Thereafter, I received a BSc from the University of Miami, and an MSc from the University of Washington’s School of Aquatic & Fishery Sciences. Currently, I am a PhD student at the University of Washington’s School of Aquatic & Fishery Sciences, co-supervised by Drs. André Punt and Ray Hilborn.

title: Lee Qi
text:
My Research
My research focuses on ecosystem-based approaches to fisheries management- looking at factors influencing fishing behaviour and management strategies for fisheries with limited data and/or capacity for management. I also make the occasional foray into stock assessment, and I work with and mentor fisheries scientists around the world.

title: Lee Qi
text:
My Life
In my spare time, I enjoy playing with my foster dog (former foster #4 Bowie pictured here), working on my bicycle, and figuring out what went wrong with my sourdough.

title: Collaboration
text: I am available for informal collaborations and/or short-term consulting contracts regarding fisheries assessments and natural resource management. Please reach out here if you’d like to discuss potential collaboration opportunities.

title: Hello!
text: My name is Lee Qi (LEE·chee). I use she/her pronouns. I’m a quantitative fisheries scientist, with a background in population dynamics modelling. Pictured here is my current foster dog Ellie.
